body: This quitHandler should be specified at a more granular level
Love it
Please add negative numbers and zero for both the float and the number of digits.

Just a coding style thing. I usually put the system headers in a file called ./src/libs/utillib/basetypes.h (these two may already be included there).

If I do put system headers in a .cpp file, I put them first.

The reason is because the linter will tell me to do that when (and if) we run the linter.
Thanks Jay. Indeed sstream was already included so I removed it. I will move iomanip over to the basetypes file.
Will do. Did you see the loss of precision on double_2_Str3 (177)? There's nothing we can do about that, right?
I agree. Variable was created for debugging purposes, I'll refactor.

Now that I think about it, this may be why I put that shirbird code in there to begin with. We need (and cannot do without) 18 decimal place accuracy. This is a hard stop.

In fact, the more I think about it, this is exactly why that original code was there to begin with. This, I think, is why Ethereum doesn't support floating point numbers.

I think this test is related https://github.com/Great-Hill-Corporation/quickBlocks/blob/287e7b3e624592c1a276044b65f7a92e849e08ff/src/libs/test-libs/etherlib/printFloat/printFloat.cpp#L32
OK great. I will make sure we have accuracy. I am reading up on this stuff. Interestingly, both the old code and the new code fail the same tests. I'm digging into why.

Let's add two more test cases:
    double_2_Str(-1e-10, 4) == "-0.0001"
    double_2_Str(128,-1) == "120"
@tjayrush I'm thinking the test cases you mention above should be `ASSERT_NOT_EQ`. Is that what you had in mind?
I made a mistake.  -1e4,5 should be -0.0001 And I just wanted to see what would happen with a negative input for width.
Very tiny style issue. Put a space after 'if'.  Otherwise, the linter (which I use sometimes, but rarely) will report.

Two things:

1) We can use the global pointer to the configuration file which is loaded at the start of every program instead of opening the file again. You can remove the CToml line and replace the getConfigStr call with

    getGlobalConfig()->getConfigStr("settings", "rpcEndpoint", "http://localhost:8545")

2) I like the word 'rpcEndpoint' but let's use the word 'provider' as they do in web3 (here: https://web3js.readthedocs.io/en/1.0/web3.html#setprovider).  So same code but use 'provider' instead of 'rpcEndpoint'.
Use 'provider' instead to mimic web3.js
Remove this line
Done

This is great, but do me a favor? Can you (1) enter the command `getBlock --latest`. You should see the Parity version string:

```
Parity-Ethereum//v2.3.4-beta-0e95db11d-20190220/x86_64-macos/rustc1.32.0
```

Let's make our string look like this up to but NOT including the operating system. So,

```
GHC-TrueBlocks//v2.3.4-alpha-COMMIT-YYYYMMDD
```

C++ has built-in defines for compile date (https://stackoverflow.com/questions/2526933/embed-timestamp-in-object-code-at-compile-time-with-c).

Also, did you think about putting this inside of getVersionStr? In that way, the change would take place everywhere. I think that would be okay.
I might like to include the branch name too, but I'll defer. The branch name can sort of be inferred by the commit hash.
Do you want the date the user built the software here, or the date of the commit?
makes sense. I scanned the file and, other than the declaration, asciiFile is not mentioned or touched -- except here in line 291.

Looking around most of my other code, you'll see I either use 'fn' or 'fileName'. In that way, as odd as it sounds, I try to keep all of the places where I open a file 'searchable.'  You can change this to `fileName` if it's more descriptive (but check for the same name elsewhere in the same function).
Good choice
Can you tell me what this file is for? I literally hate it.
Why is this commented out?
[consistent management of dependencies](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53837919/should-go-sum-file-be-checked-in-to-the-git-repository)

Instead of blaze being a normal go project in the src folder of our GOPATH, it's all the way out here in trueblocks-core/src/go-apps. This goes against "go best practices" about project structure. In response I made modules of the go projects and now we don't need to set a GOPATH.
I prefer only a single blank line, never two.

diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,30 @@
+# Decorators
+from functools import wraps
+
+
+def my_logger(orig_func):
+    import logging
+    logging.basicConfig(filename='{}.log'.format(orig_func.__name__), level=logging.INFO)
+
+    @wraps(orig_func)
+    def wrapper(*args, **kwargs):
+        logging.info(
+            'Ran with args: {}, and kwargs: {}'.format(args, kwargs))
+        return orig_func(*args, **kwargs)
+
+    return wrapper
+
body: Single blank line please.
